name: Aardonyx
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Prosauropoda, Anchisauria
namedBy: Yates, Bonnan, Neveling, Chinsamy and Blackbeard 2010 (2009)
description: Aardonyx is known from 2 immature individuals. Adults would have been much larger, probably over 10m.Aardonyx would have been largely bipedal (walking on 2 legs) but also capable of walking on all 4 legs. This and its way of feeding are transitional features between those of basal sauropodomorphs and the more derived sauropods (large dinosaurs that walked on all fours) that came later.

name: Abelisaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Ceratosauria, Abelisauridae, Abelisaurinae
description:
Abelisaurus, a genus of theropod dinosaur, inhabited the Late Cretaceous Period, flourishing approximately 70 to 66 million years ago. This medium-sized predator measured around 7 to 9 meters (23 to 30 feet) in length, with an estimated weight of 1 to 2 metric tons (1.1 to 2.2 short tons). Its physique adhered to the typical theropod blueprint, featuring a stout skull, short forelimbs with three fingers, and robust hind limbs optimized for bipedal locomotion. Notably, Abelisaurus boasted a distinctive crest or ridge atop its skull, possibly employed for display or species recognition.

Native to what is now South America, particularly Argentina, Abelisaurus roamed diverse landscapes encompassing forests, plains, and river valleys. As a carnivore, it subsisted on a diet of smaller dinosaurs and other fauna within its ecosystem, utilizing its sharp teeth and powerful jaws for efficient predation. While specific details regarding its behavior remain speculative due to limited fossil evidence, Abelisaurus likely employed ambush tactics or short-distance pursuits to capture prey, possibly hunting alone or in groups.

Abelisaurus stands as a compelling example of the diverse theropod fauna that thrived during the Late Cretaceous in South America, offering valuable insights into the evolutionary adaptations and ecological roles of predatory dinosaurs in this region during prehistoric times.

name: Achelousaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Neornithischia, Cerapoda, Marginocephalia, Ceratopsia, Neoceratopsia, Coronosauria, Ceratopsidae, Centrosaurinae
description: Achelousaurus is a genus of ceratopsid dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous Period, approximately 74 to 66 million years ago. This herbivorous dinosaur was characterized by its large, elaborate skull adorned with horns and frills, similar to other ceratopsids. The skull of Achelousaurus features a prominent nasal horn and two smaller horns above its eyes, along with a frill extending from the back of its head. This frill had distinctive fenestrae (openings) and unique ornamentation patterns, which varied among individuals and likely played a role in species recognition or display. Achelousaurus is believed to have been a quadrupedal animal, using its powerful limbs to move through its environment and forage for vegetation. Fossil specimens have been found in North America, primarily in regions that are part of present-day Montana and South Dakota. As a member of the ceratopsid family, Achelousaurus represents an important component of Late Cretaceous ecosystems, contributing to our understanding of dinosaur diversity and evolution during this period.

name: Aegyptosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Macronaria, Camarasauromorpha, Titanosauriformes, Titanosauria
description:
Aegyptosaurus is a genus of sauropod dinosaur that existed during the Late Cretaceous Period, approximately 95 to 93 million years ago. Belonging to the family Titanosauridae, Aegyptosaurus was a large, long-necked herbivore characterized by its immense size and robust skeletal structure. Fossil specimens suggest that it reached lengths of up to 15 to 18 meters (49 to 59 feet) and weighed several metric tons.

This dinosaur had a long neck, a bulky body, and a relatively small head in proportion to its massive body size. Aegyptosaurus possessed a long tail that likely served as a counterbalance to its lengthy neck. Its limbs were stout and column-like, supporting its colossal weight. Aegyptosaurus is thought to have been a quadrupedal animal, using all four limbs to support itself while moving.

Fossil remains of Aegyptosaurus have been discovered in North Africa, particularly in present-day Egypt and Niger. These findings contribute to our understanding of sauropod diversity and distribution during the Late Cretaceous Period. As a member of the titanosaurs, Aegyptosaurus represents one of the many fascinating herbivorous dinosaurs that roamed the ancient landscapes millions of years ago, playing a crucial ecological role in their ecosystems.

name: Afrovenator
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Megalosauridae, Eustreptospondylinae
namedBy: Sereno, Wilson, Larsson, Dutheil and Sues (1944)
description: A medium-sized theropod dinosaur from the Middle Jurassic period, roamed the ancient landscapes of what is now Niger, West Africa, approximately 164 to 161 million years ago. With a slender build and a length of around 7 to 9 meters, this "African hunter" possessed a long, narrow skull lined with sharp, serrated teeth, ideal for capturing prey. Its powerful hind legs enabled swift pursuits, while its smaller forelimbs likely aided in grasping. Likely a solitary or small-group hunter, Afrovenator was an agile carnivore, preying on smaller dinosaurs and other animals in its lush, tropical habitat, contributing to the intricate web of life during its time.

name: Alamosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Macronaria, Camarasauromorpha, Titanosauriformes, Titanosauria, Lithostrotia
description: This is the only Late Cretaceous sauropod that has been found in North America.

name: Albertosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Tyrannosauroidea, Tyrannosauridae, Albertosaurinae
description: Albertosaurus was a close relative of Tyrannosaurus, but smaller and not as heavily built.

name: Alectrosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Tyrannosauroidea
description: A genus of theropod dinosaur from the Late Cretaceous period, inhabited the ancient landscapes of what is now Asia, particularly Mongolia, approximately 80 million years ago. With a length of around 5 to 6 meters, Alectrosaurus possessed a robust body and a relatively large skull equipped with sharp, serrated teeth, indicating its carnivorous diet. Its limbs were well-adapted for mobility, with strong hind legs suggesting it was a swift runner, while its forelimbs were shorter and likely served a grasping function. As a predator, Alectrosaurus likely hunted smaller dinosaurs and other prey in its ecosystem, contributing to the complex dynamics of Late Cretaceous Asia.

name: Allosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Tetanurae, Avetheropoda, Carnosauria, Allosauroidea, Allosauridae
description: The teeth of Allosaurus  were 5-10cm long and curved backwards to prevent prey from escaping.

name: Alvarezsaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Tetanurae, Avetheropoda, Coelurosauria, Tyrannoraptora, Maniraptoriformes, Maniraptora, Alvarezsauridae
description: Alvarezsaurus may have been feathered.

name: Amargasaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Diplodocoidea, Dicraeosauridae
description: This dinosaur had a double row of spines along its back which may have supported a twin 'sail' of skin. The spines on its neck vertebrae were incredibly long.

name: Ammosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Prosauropoda, Anchisauria, Anchisauridae
description: This dinosaur was very similar to Anchisaurus.

name: Amygdalodon
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda
description: Amygdalodon is known from a single partial skeleton.

name: Anchiceratops
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Neornithischia, Cerapoda, Marginocephalia, Ceratopsia, Neoceratopsia, Coronosauria, Ceratopsidae, Chasmosaurinae
description: A genus of ceratopsid dinosaur from the Late Cretaceous period, roamed the ancient landscapes of what is now North America, particularly Alberta, Canada, approximately 68 to 66 million years ago. Characterized by a large frill adorned with spikes and a prominent nasal horn, Anchiceratops reached lengths of around 5 to 6 meters and weighed several tons. Its body was stout and quadrupedal, with a robust build and powerful limbs. Anchiceratops was a herbivore, likely feeding on low-lying vegetation with its sharp beak and dental batteries. This dinosaur likely lived in herds, contributing to the biodiversity and ecosystem dynamics of Late Cretaceous North America.

name: Anchisaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Prosauropoda, Anchisauria, Anchisauridae
description: A genus of early sauropodomorph dinosaur from the Late Triassic period, inhabited what is now North America around 200 to 190 million years ago. With a slender build and reaching lengths of about 2 to 4 meters, this herbivorous dinosaur possessed a small head with leaf-shaped teeth adapted for browsing on vegetation. Its long neck and tail, along with its bipedal stance, suggest it was capable of both browsing on low-lying vegetation and moving swiftly on its hind legs. Anchisaurus likely lived in social groups and played a role in the ecosystem dynamics of its time, contributing to the early diversification of dinosaurs during the Late Triassic.

name: Ankylosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Thyreophora, Ankylosauria, Ankylosauridae
description: Ankylosaurus lived during the Late Cretaceous Period in what is now North America. This armoured dinosaur had bony plates covering its body and a heavy club at the end of its tail.Though it's the most famous member of the ankylosaur group, it's not the best understood. Scientists still haven't found an entire Ankylosaurus skeleton. Some other types of ankylosaurs, such as Zuul, are known from many more bones.But we do have enough Ankylosaurus remains to see that it may have been one of the biggest ankylosaurs.The first Ankylosaurus bones were found in 1906 at the Hell Creek Formation in Montana, USA. Barnum Brown led the fossil hunting trip - the same scientist who led the discovery of Tyrannosaurus rex a few years earlier.These Ankylosaurus fossils weren't very complete. The distinctive tail club wasn't discovered until much later.Barnum and his team found several pieces of armour, but they had separated from the main skeleton. Even today, nobody knows exactly how Ankylosaurus' back armour should be arranged.We can't say for sure how any dinosaur behaved when it was alive. Scientists can only go on fossils and comparisons with living animals.We know that as a plant eater, Ankylosaurus wouldn't have used its tail club to attack prey. It probably used the club to defend itself against big predators.Being herbivorous doesn't mean Ankylosaurus was harmless. Many modern plant-eating animals, such as elephants and hippos, can be very aggressive and dangerous. We may never know whether Ankylosaurus was gentle in nature!This hefty dinosaur probably moved very slowly most of the time, although it might have been able to move faster when needed.Ankylosaurus probably couldn't move its tail club up and down much, but could swing it powerfully from side to side - delivering devastating swipes to any would-be predators.Experts think Ankylosaurus grazed on low-growing plants. It probably wasn't picky - eating many kinds of ferns, shrubs and fruit.Ankylosaurus would've needed to eat around 60 kilogrammes of plant matter a day. That's about the same as a modern elephant.Some scientists think Ankylosaurus might have been able to use its front limbs for digging. If so, perhaps it also ate roots and any other kinds of plant and animal matter it could dig up.Several members of the ankylosaur group lacked the bony tail clubs seen in Ankylosaurus and others such as Tarchia, but were otherwise still covered in armour.These clubless ankylosaurs include Nodosaurus, Panoplosaurus and the British dinosaur Polacanthus.

name: Anserimimus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Ornithomimosauria, Ornithomimidae
description: A genus of ornithomimid dinosaur from the Late Cretaceous period, roamed the ancient landscapes of what is now Mongolia approximately 70 to 68 million years ago. Characterized by its long, slender body and ostrich-like appearance, Anserimimus reached lengths of around 3 to 4 meters. It possessed a toothless beak and sharp claws on its hands, indicating its herbivorous diet and possibly omnivorous habits. Anserimimus likely moved swiftly on its long hind legs and may have been capable of both bipedal and quadrupedal locomotion. This dinosaur likely lived in social groups and played a role in the ecosystem dynamics of Late Cretaceous Mongolia, contributing to the diversity of its time.

name: Antarctosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Macronaria, Camarasauromorpha, Titanosauriformes, Titanosauria, Lithostrotia
description: A genus of sauropod dinosaur from the Late Cretaceous period, inhabited the ancient southern continents, particularly what is now South America and Antarctica, around 70 to 65 million years ago. This massive herbivore reached lengths of up to 20 meters or more, with a long neck and tail and a massive body supported by four sturdy legs. Its skull was relatively small in proportion to its body, equipped with a set of peg-like teeth suited for processing plant material. Antarctosaurus likely roamed in herds, browsing on vegetation to sustain its enormous size. Its presence in Antarctica suggests a remarkable adaptation to polar climates. Antarctosaurus played a significant role in the Late Cretaceous ecosystems of Gondwana, contributing to the overall biodiversity and shaping the landscape through its feeding habits and movements.

name: Apatosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Diplodocoidea, Diplodocidae
description: Apatosaurus was a large sauropod dinosaur. It lived around 150 million years ago in the Late Jurassic Period, in an area that is now North America.Like all sauropods, Apatosaurus ate plants.Young Apatosaurus individuals grew up quickly. They took around 10 years to reach full adult size.Apatosaurus lived alongside Stegosaurus, Diplodocus and Allosaurus.Their fossils were found in the Morrison Formation, a sequence of rocks that covers a huge area spanning several US states, including Wyoming, Colorado and Montana. Many dinosaurs have been discovered there.During the Late Jurassic the environment was semi-arid, with forests, rivers and floodplains. There were distinct wet and dry seasons.Apatosaurus had a long, narrow tail that it might have used as a whip.The animal's huge size would also have helped to protect it from smaller predators, which may have found Apatosaurus too big to take on. Living in herds gave extra protection.The name Apatosaurus comes from Greek words meaning 'deceptive lizard'. The scientist who named this dinosaur, Othniel Charles Marsh, felt that some of the fossil bones were confusing to identify. They seemed to resemble the bones of a sea reptile.For more than 100 years, most scientists stopped using the well-known dinosaur name Brontosaurus. They thought that Brontosaurus and Apatosaurus fossils were the same thing.But based on a study done in 2015, experts now think that the two dinosaurs are separate after all, although they are closely related.Apatosaurus went extinct 145 million years ago, at the end of the Jurassic Period.

name: Aralosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Ornithopoda, Hadrosauridae, Euhadrosauria, Hadrosaurinae
description: A genus of dinosaur from the Late Cretaceous period, is known primarily from fragmentary remains discovered in what is now Kazakhstan. Though limited fossil evidence exists, Aralosaurus is believed to have been a medium-sized herbivore, possibly reaching lengths of around 5 to 7 meters. It likely belonged to the hadrosaurid family, characterized by its duck-billed appearance and toothless beak, adapted for feeding on vegetation. Aralosaurus likely inhabited the coastal regions of its ancient environment, foraging on a variety of plants to sustain its dietary needs. While much about Aralosaurus remains uncertain due to the scarcity of fossils, it represents an important piece in understanding the diversity of Late Cretaceous dinosaurs in Central Asia.

name: Archaeopteryx
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Paraves, Archaeopterygidae
description: Archaeopteryx was a small, bird-like dinosaur. It lived during the Late Jurassic Period in what is now Europe.The discovery of the first Archaeopteryx fossil in Germany in 1861 caused a lot of confusion. No birds were known from so far back. Some people even thought it might be an angel.Since then, multiple fossils of Archaeopteryx have been discovered. Many show clear evidence of long feathers. But we don't know whether Archaeopteryx was fully able to fly or if it could only glide.Archaeopteryx also has a common name - Urvogel, a German name meaning 'primeval bird'.Strictly speaking, all birds are dinosaurs. But not all dinosaurs are birds. Scientists sometimes use the term 'non-avian dinosaurs' when talking about prehistoric dinosaurs that aren't birds.The line between bird and non-avian dinosaur can be vague, and many experts have discussed which way to class Archaeopteryx. For many years, scientists spoke about it as an ancient bird. These days, many people believe it should be called a dinosaur.Ultimately, categories like bird and non-avian dinosaur are invented by humans. The natural world doesn't always fit neatly into them. Animals such as Archaeopteryx that could sit across two or more categories are sometimes called transitional fossils.While Archaeopteryx is sometimes called the first bird or the earliest bird, scientists now think that there could be even older bird ancestors. Dinosaurs such as Anchiornis and Aurornis might sit even further back on the bird branch of the dinosaur family tree. If so, they're even earlier relatives of true birds. It's very difficult to say for sure.Archaeopteryx had some features in common with the birds of today. It had broad feathered wings and a small body, roughly the size of a magpie.After comparing its eyes to those of modern birds and reptiles, experts concluded that Archaeopteryx was probably diurnal. This means that it would have been active during the day and slept at night, like many of today's birds.We don't know whether Archaeopteryx mostly lived on the ground or in trees. Some scientists think it might have been equally comfortable with either, like a crow.Unlike modern birds, however, Archaeopteryx had sharp teeth and a long, bony tail.Many specimens of Archaeopteryx have been recovered over the years. All are from the limestone quarries near Solnhofen in Germany.In the Jurassic Period, this area was a lagoon surrounded by sub-tropical islands. Other small creatures such as insects and lizards - which Archaeopteryx may have preyed on - have been unearthed there too. So have some pterosaurs - flying reptiles - and the small dinosaur Compsognathus.The first Archaeopteryx fossil ever found was a single feather.Later, full skeletons were discovered showing feather impressions. We bought the first of these in 1862. It is now known as 'the London specimen' and is on display in our Cadogan gallery.There has since been debate over whether the first feather discovered really belongs to Archaeopteryx.Two years before the discovery of Archaeopteryx, Charles Darwin had just written On the Origin of Species. The book was the first to lay out the theory of evolution.Many people back then - scientists included - strongly disagreed with Darwin's concept and claimed that it wasn't possible for animals to evolve over time. But the discovery of the Archaeopteryx fossils, clearly showing a feathered and bird-like dinosaur, seemed to prove that dinosaurs had evolved into birds.Even 100 years later, there were still those who didn't accept it. Some people published articles claiming that the feathers must be fake. The controversy didn't last long, however, as our scientists were able to show that the fossils were real.The discovery of Archaeopteryx was a landmark moment for dinosaur scientists, and it is still considered to be one of the most important finds in history.It's usually almost impossible for scientists to know what colour a dinosaur would have been in life.But thanks to modern scanning technology, experts have been able to find out the colour of one Archaeopteryx wing feather - which seems to have been jet-black.We don't know whether Archaeopteryx was black all over or only on its wings.

name: Archaeornithomimus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Ornithomimosauria, Ornithomimidae
description: A genus of ornithomimid theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, around 70 million years ago. It was a bipedal dinosaur characterized by its long, slender legs, and ostrich-like appearance. Archaeornithomimus had a toothless beak, indicating it was likely an herbivore or omnivore, feeding on plants and small animals. It measured about 3 to 4 meters (10 to 13 feet) in length and is believed to have been a fast runner, possibly capable of speeds similar to modern ostriches. Fossils of Archaeornithomimus have been discovered in Asia, particularly in what is now Mongolia and China.

name: Argentinosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Macronaria, Camarasauromorpha, Titanosauriformes, Titanosauria
description: The exact size of Argentinosaurus is hard to estimate due to the incompleteness of its fossilised remains. But it is one of the largest land animals ever found. It carried on growing throughout most of its lifetime. Other similarly massive dinosaurs include Patagotitan and Puertasaurus. They were all titanosaurs, a type of sauropod.Argentinosaurus probably used its long neck to sweep the ground or to reach high up in search of vegetation. The hatchlings of Argentinosaurus would have taken 15 years to grow to adulthood and in that time they would have been very vulnerable to predators, such as Giganotosaurus.

name: Arrhinoceratops
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Neornithischia, Cerapoda, Marginocephalia, Ceratopsia, Neoceratopsia, Coronosauria, Ceratopsidae, Chasmosaurinae
description: The only undisputed specimen of Arrhinoceratops is a skull.

name: Atlascopcosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Ornithopoda, Euornithopoda
description: Atlascopcosaurus is a genus of small herbivorous dinosaur that lived during the Early Cretaceous period, approximately 110 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as ornithopods and was characterized by its bipedal stance and beak-like mouth. Fossils of Atlascopcosaurus have been found in Australia, particularly in the state of Victoria. It was a relatively small dinosaur, estimated to have been around 1 to 2 meters (3 to 6 feet) in length. Despite its small size, Atlascopcosaurus likely played an important role in its ecosystem as a herbivore, feeding on vegetation.

name: Austrosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Macronaria, Camarasauromorpha, Titanosauriformes, Titanosauria
description: Dorsal vertebrae (part of the backbone) and limb remains of Austrosaurus have been found.

name: Avaceratops
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Neornithischia, Cerapoda, Marginocephalia, Ceratopsia, Neoceratopsia, Coronosauria, Ceratopsidae, Centrosaurinae
description: Avaceratops is a genus of ceratopsian dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, around 75 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as ceratopsids, which are characterized by their large frills and horns. Avaceratops was a relatively small ceratopsian, measuring about 2 to 3 meters (6 to 10 feet) in length. It had a beak-like mouth, a frill at the back of its skull, and possibly one or two horns on its snout. Fossils of Avaceratops have been found in North America, particularly in the states of Montana and Wyoming. This dinosaur likely fed on low-lying vegetation and may have lived in herds for protection against predators.

name: Avimimus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Tetanurae, Avetheropoda, Coelurosauria, Tyrannoraptora, Maniraptoriformes, Maniraptora, Oviraptorosauria, Avimimidae
description: Avimimus is a genus of theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, around 70 million years ago. It was a member of the group known as oviraptorosaurs, characterized by their toothless beaks and sometimes elaborate crests. Avimimus was relatively small, reaching lengths of about 1.5 to 2 meters (5 to 6.5 feet). It had a bird-like appearance, with long legs, a long tail, and short arms ending in three-fingered hands. Its name, "Avimimus," means "bird mimic," reflecting its bird-like features. Fossils of Avimimus have been found in Mongolia. It is believed to have been an omnivore, feeding on a diet of plants, small animals, and possibly eggs. Its precise lifestyle and behavior remain topics of study and debate among paleontologists.

name: Bagaceratops
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Neornithischia, Cerapoda, Marginocephalia, Ceratopsia, Neoceratopsia, Bagaceratopsidae
description: N/A

name: Barapasaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Cetiosauridae
description: Barapasaurus was a primitive but very large sauropod.

name: Barosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Diplodocoidea, Diplodocidae
description: Barosaurus is a genus of sauropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Jurassic period, approximately 155 to 150 million years ago. It was a massive, long-necked herbivore belonging to the group known as diplodocids. Barosaurus is notable for its exceptionally long neck and tail, which contributed to its overall length of around 25 to 30 meters (82 to 98 feet). Despite its enormous size, Barosaurus had a relatively slender build compared to other sauropods. Fossils of Barosaurus have been found in North America, primarily in the Morrison Formation of Utah and Wyoming. It is closely related to Diplodocus and Apatosaurus. The lifestyle and behavior of Barosaurus are inferred to have involved feeding on vegetation from tall trees, using its long neck to reach high branches.

name: Becklespinax
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Tetanurae
description: Becklespinax is a genus of theropod dinosaur that lived during the Early Cretaceous period, approximately 140 million years ago. It is known from fragmentary fossil remains discovered in England. Becklespinax is classified within the family Megalosauridae, which includes various medium to large-sized carnivorous dinosaurs. The exact size and appearance of Becklespinax remain uncertain due to the limited fossil material available. However, it is believed to have been a bipedal predator, likely possessing sharp teeth and claws for hunting prey. Despite its relative obscurity compared to other theropods, Becklespinax provides valuable insights into the diversity of dinosaurs during the Early Cretaceous in Europe.

name: Borogovia
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Paraves, Eumaniraptoria, Troodontidae
description: Only partial hindlimbs of this dinosaur have been found, so reconstructions are speculative. It was named after Lewis Carroll's borogoves from the poem Jabberwocky, published in 1871.

name: Brachiosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Macronaria, Camarasauromorpha, Titanosauriformes, Brachiosauridae
description: Brachiosaurus held its head very high. It is likely to have eaten the leaves on tall tree-like plants.

name: Brachylophosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Ornithopoda, Hadrosauridae, Euhadrosauria, Hadrosaurinae
description:
Brachylophosaurus is a genus of hadrosaurid dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, around 76.5 to 75 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs commonly known as "duck-billed" or hadrosaurid dinosaurs. Brachylophosaurus is notable for the distinctive bony crest on top of its head, which resembles a hatchet or a spade, giving it its name, which means "short-crested lizard." Fossils of Brachylophosaurus have been found in North America, primarily in Montana, Wyoming, and Alberta, Canada.

This dinosaur reached lengths of about 9 to 12 meters (30 to 40 feet) and had a relatively stout body. It walked on four legs but could also rear up on its hind legs to reach vegetation. Like other hadrosaurs, Brachylophosaurus was herbivorous, feeding on a variety of plants such as ferns, conifers, and flowering plants. It likely lived in herds for protection against predators and may have engaged in complex social behaviors. Brachylophosaurus is an important species for understanding the diversity and ecology of Late Cretaceous dinosaurs in North America.

name: Camarasaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Macronaria, Camarasauromorpha, Camarasauridae
description: Camarasaurus used rows of close-set teeth to strip the leaves from trees and shrubs. Food was ground by stones in the stomach.

name: Camptosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Ornithopoda, Euornithopoda, Iguanadontia, Euiguanadontia, Dryomorpha, Ankylopollexia
description:
Camptosaurus is a genus of ornithopod dinosaur that lived during the Late Jurassic period, approximately 156 to 150 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as iguanodonts and was characterized by its bipedal stance, long hind limbs, and relatively short forelimbs. Camptosaurus had a beak-like mouth with teeth suited for chewing plant material, indicating it was an herbivore. Fossils of Camptosaurus have been found in North America, particularly in the Morrison Formation of Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming.

This dinosaur measured around 5 to 7 meters (16 to 23 feet) in length and had a relatively slender build compared to other ornithopods. It likely browsed on low-lying vegetation and may have lived in herds for protection against predators. Camptosaurus is important in paleontology as it represents one of the earlier-known ornithopod dinosaurs and provides valuable insights into the evolutionary history of herbivorous dinosaurs during the Late Jurassic period.

name: Carcharodontosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Carcharodontosauridae
description: Carcharodontosaurus was a very large meat-eating dinosaur.It is named after Carcharodon, the scientific name for several types of shark - of which the great white shark is the only living example.Carcharodontosaurus teeth look a lot like shark teeth. Like Tyrannosaurus, it had about 60 of them.Carcharodontosaurus fossils have been found across North Africa in Algeria, Egypt and Morocco.In the Late Cretaceous, this region was warm and humid with rainforests, rivers and lakes.Carcharodontosaurus lived alongside many other dinosaurs, including sauropods such as Paralititan and Rebbachisaurus and the theropods Spinosaurus and Deltadromeus.Scientists aren't sure what Carcharodontosaurus ate. It most likely fed on large prey such as plant-eating dinosaurs.Carcharodontosaurus had a much less powerful bite than Tyrannosaurus and more fragile teeth. But while it probably didn't crush bones, its teeth were suited to ripping flesh.Carcharodontosaurus is one of the largest carnivorous dinosaurs known. At one point, scientists thought its skull might be the longest ever found. It was around 1.6 metres in length.The full animal could reach lengths of at least 12.5 metres - a size comparable to Tyrannosaurus.Giganotosaurus may have been even larger than both dinosaurs. A lack of complete remains makes it hard to be sure.Carcharodontosaurus was a close relative of Giganotosaurus.Both dinosaurs are carcharodontosaurs - a group that also contains several other interesting dinosaurs, such as the peculiar-looking Concavenator and the British theropod Neovenator.Yet Carcharodontosaurus and Giganotosaurus didn't live in the same place. Giganotosaurus is found in South America.The close relation of these two dinosaurs may be because Africa and South America were once connected. They broke apart during the Cretaceous Period. Scientists are still debating exactly when the separation occurred.

name: Carnotaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Ceratosauria, Abelisauridae
description: Carnotaurus was a meat-eating dinosaur with two horns on the top of its head and very small arms.It had an unusually short snout and its head was very narrow when viewed from the front.Scientists have found lots of skin impressions for this dinosaur, so we know that it had scales over much of its body. It's unlikely that Carnotaurus or its relatives had feathers - no evidence of them has ever been found.We also don't have a complete skeleton. So far, nobody has ever found the tail or lower legs of Carnotaurus. This means we must use some guesswork based on the remains of this dinosaur's close relatives to do a full-body reconstruction.Nobody is quite sure what Carnotaurus' horns were for. Some experts think the dinosaur might have used them to fight rivals or attack prey.Another idea is that the horns might have helped to attract a mate or identify other Carnotaurus.Experts believe that Carnotaurus' ancestors would have had longer arms. Over time the arms got smaller and less useful.Carnotaurus probably didn't use its arms for much. They were a leftover trait from the dinosaur's earlier ancestors.Scientists call this a vestigial feature. It comes from the word 'vestige', meaning 'a small trace of something that existed a long time ago'.Many animals have vestigial features, including humans. For example, you still have a tailbone in your skeleton, even though you don't have a tail!In his novel The Lost World - the sequel to Jurassic Park - Michael Crichton described Carnotaurus as able to disguise itself with changing skin colours, like a chameleon.We don't have evidence that any dinosaur ever had this ability. If they did, we wouldn't be able to tell from fossil remains.It's always possible that any given dinosaur might have had an unusual or surprising feature that isn't shown in fossils. Fiction is a great place to explore interesting ideas.Although Carnotaurus looked unusual with its tiny arms and short snout, it wasn't the only dinosaur like this.Carnotaurus was part of the abelisaur group. These closely related dinosaurs shared similar characteristics. But Carnotaurus is the only one known to have two horns on its head.Other abelisaurs include Abelisaurus itself, Majungasaurus and the Indian predator Rajasaurus.Carnotaurus and Tyrannosaurus weren't very closely related.The two dinosaurs do share some similarities - both are meat-eating dinosaurs that walked on two legs. But they are also quite different.Tyrannosaurs had more powerful jaws and teeth than abelisaurs, as well as longer arms with two-fingered hands. Abelisaurs had four fingers on each hand. Tyrannosaurs could also grow much larger.Carnotaurus and Tyrannosaurus belong to two different dinosaur groups - ceratosaurs and coelurosaurs. These groups might have been evolving apart for more than 100 million years, since the Late Triassic Period.Carnotaurus fossils have only been found in Argentina. They occur in Late Cretaceous rocks that may have formed from the deposits of estuaries or tidal flats.We know Carnotaurus shared its environment with other dinosaurs. Researchers have found partial remains of as-yet unnamed ankylosaurs and hadrosaurs in the same area, but we don't know exactly what these dinosaurs were like.Although it was clearly a meat-eater, nobody knows for sure what types of animals Carnotaurus hunted.Many experts think it probably preyed on large sauropod dinosaurs. Teeth belonging to related abelisaurs have been found with sauropod remains, so it seems likely.Carnotaurus had a more flexible lower jaw than most other carnivorous dinosaurs. It may have been able to open its jaw wide, like a snake, to swallow big chunks of meat.Originally, researchers thought that the flexible jaw meant Carnotaurus didn't have a very strong bite. But more recent studies contradict this. Some experts think Carnotaurus may even have had a stronger bite force than an American alligator, the most powerful biting creature alive today.When you're talking about more than one dinosaur of a particular kind, you don't need to put an 's' on the end.You can think of it the same way as you would say 'two sheep'.This applies to all dinosaur names - so you can say 'two Carnotaurus' or 'five Velociraptor'.

name: Centrosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Neornithischia, Cerapoda, Marginocephalia, Ceratopsia, Neoceratopsia, Coronosauria, Ceratopsidae, Centrosaurinae
description: Centrosaurus had one horn on its snout and spines around the back of its neck frill.

name: Ceratosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Ceratosauria, Neoceratosauria
description: Ceratosaurus means 'horned lizard'. The dinosaur was given this name because it had a row of sharp horns on its head and a row of small, bony pieces of armour running along its back. It is not known what this body armour was for, but it could have been for protection from attack by other Ceratosaurus or larger theropods such as Allosaurus and Torvosaurus.Scientists have estimated that Ceratosaurus was about six to seven metres long. It seems to have been quite a rare animal - remains of it are much rarer than those of the Allosaurus that lived alongside it.Ceratosaurus was one of the biggest hunters in the Jurassic Period. Its prey probably included plant-eating dinosaurs, but some scientists have suggested that it may have fed upon aquatic animals such as fish, turtles and crocodiles.Ceratosaurus is remarkable for the very long, slender teeth in its upper jaw. These teeth could be over nine centimetres long, nearly as long as the lower jaw was deep, so they would almost stick out beyond it when the mouth was closed. Nobody really knows why the teeth were so long, but they may have helped it inflict deep, slashing wounds in prey.

name: Cetiosauriscus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Diplodocoidea
description:
Cetiosauriscus is a genus of sauropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Jurassic period, around 166 to 161 million years ago. It belonged to the group known as cetiosaurids, which were long-necked, herbivorous dinosaurs. Cetiosauriscus was originally described based on fragmentary remains found in England, although subsequent research suggests that these remains may represent a mixture of different dinosaur species. As a result, the exact classification and appearance of Cetiosauriscus remain uncertain.

However, based on the available fossil evidence, Cetiosauriscus is inferred to have been a large, quadrupedal dinosaur with a long neck and tail. It likely reached lengths of around 15 to 20 meters (49 to 66 feet) or possibly more. Like other sauropods, Cetiosauriscus would have been a herbivore, using its elongated neck to reach high vegetation. Despite the uncertainty surrounding its classification, Cetiosauriscus is significant in understanding the diversity and evolution of sauropod dinosaurs during the Late Jurassic period.

name: Cetiosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Cetiosauridae
description:
Cetiosaurus is a genus of sauropod dinosaur that lived during the Middle Jurassic period, around 166 to 164 million years ago. It was one of the earliest known sauropods and played a significant role in the study of dinosaur paleontology. Cetiosaurus was first discovered in England in the early 19th century, making it one of the first dinosaurs to be scientifically described.

This dinosaur was a massive, long-necked herbivore with a small head and a relatively long tail. It reached lengths of about 15 to 20 meters (49 to 66 feet) and had a quadrupedal stance, with column-like legs supporting its enormous body. Cetiosaurus likely browsed on vegetation, using its long neck to reach high branches. Fossils of Cetiosaurus have been found in England and possibly in other parts of Europe.

Although initially described based on limited fossil material, Cetiosaurus has been the subject of ongoing research and debate in paleontology, contributing to our understanding of sauropod anatomy, behavior, and evolution.

name: Chasmosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Neornithischia, Cerapoda, Marginocephalia, Ceratopsia, Neoceratopsia, Coronosauria, Ceratopsidae, Chasmosaurinae
description: Chasmosaurus had a small nose horn, blunt brow horns and a long neck frill with holes.

name: Chindesaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Herrerasauridae
description: Chindesaurus had a long whip-like tail and long legs. No skull has been found, so its reconstruction is guesswork based on similar dinosaurs.

name: Chinshakiangosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda
description: Chinshakiangosaurus is only known from a fragmentary skeleton.

name: Citipati
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Tetanurae, Avetheropoda, Coelurosauria, Tyrannoraptora, Maniraptoriformes, Maniraptora, Oviraptorosauria, Caenagnathoidea, Oviraptoridae, Oviraptorinae
description:
Citipati is a genus of oviraptorid theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 70 million years ago. It was discovered in Mongolia and is known for its distinctive appearance and behavior. Citipati was a relatively small dinosaur, measuring about 2 meters (6.6 feet) in length.

One of the most remarkable features of Citipati is the discovery of a nesting site with fossilized eggs in close association with adult specimens. This finding suggests that Citipati, like other oviraptorids, may have exhibited brooding behavior, incubating its eggs in a manner similar to modern birds. The posture of the adult Citipati specimens found in association with the eggs suggests that they were sitting atop the nest in a bird-like manner, possibly using their feathers to cover and protect the eggs.

Citipati is also notable for its unusual, cassowary-like crest on its head, which may have been used for display or communication purposes. Its name, Citipati, is derived from a Sanskrit word meaning "funeral pyre lord" and refers to a figure in Buddhist mythology.

Overall, Citipati provides valuable insights into the reproductive behavior and appearance of oviraptorid dinosaurs, as well as the broader evolution of theropod dinosaurs towards bird-like characteristics.

name: Coelophysis
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Coelophysoidea, Coelophysidae
description: In the Late Triassic Period dinosaurs were not at the top of the food chain. Instead, early large reptiles called phytosaurs and rauisuchids domintated.Early meat-eating dinosaurs like Coelophysis relied on their speed and agility to catch a variety of animals like insects and small reptiles. The sharp teeth and grasping claws of Coelophysis would have helped them to hold and kill their food.A fossil find of an adult skeleton with what appeared to be young Coelophysis bones inside its rib cage led scientists to speculate that Coelophysis ate each other when the opportunity arose.Recent analysis has disproved this, however, by showing that the bones inside the ribcage are not a baby Coelophysis after all, but belong to a small crocodile.Coelophysis means 'hollow form' and this comes from the hollow limb bones. This feature was shared by many other dinosaurs, and would have given Coelophysis a lightly-built body, helping it to be a swift, agile hunter.

name: Coelurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Tetanurae, Avetheropoda, Coelurosauria
description:
Coelurus is a genus of small theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Jurassic period, around 155 to 145 million years ago. It belonged to the group known as coelurosaurs, which includes some of the most bird-like dinosaurs. Coelurus had a slender build, with long legs and arms, and it likely walked on two legs. Fossils of Coelurus have been found in North America, particularly in the Morrison Formation of Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming.

Despite being relatively small, around 2 to 3 meters (6.6 to 9.8 feet) in length, Coelurus was a carnivore, using its sharp teeth and agile body to hunt small prey such as insects, lizards, and possibly small mammals. Its name, which means "hollow tail," refers to the hollow structure of its tail bones. Despite its importance in early paleontological research, Coelurus is known from incomplete fossil material, making it challenging to reconstruct its appearance and behavior with certainty. However, it represents an important part of the evolutionary history of small theropod dinosaurs.

name: Coloradisaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Prosauropoda, Plateosauria, Plateosauridae
description:
Coloradisaurus is a genus of prosauropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Triassic period, approximately 230 to 220 million years ago. It is one of the earliest known dinosaurs and represents an early stage in the evolution of the larger, long-necked sauropodomorph dinosaurs. Fossils of Coloradisaurus have been found in Argentina, particularly in the Ischigualasto Formation.

Coloradisaurus was a relatively small dinosaur, measuring around 2 to 3 meters (6.6 to 9.8 feet) in length. It had a bipedal stance, with longer hind limbs than forelimbs, suggesting it was primarily a bipedal walker. Its long neck and small head indicate that it was likely an herbivore, feeding on low-lying vegetation. Coloradisaurus represents an important stage in the early evolution of dinosaurs, providing insights into the transition from more primitive reptiles to the diverse group of dinosaurs that would dominate terrestrial ecosystems for millions of years.

name: Conchoraptor
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Tetanurae, Avetheropoda, Coelurosauria, Tyrannoraptora, Maniraptoriformes, Maniraptora, Oviraptorosauria, Caenagnathoidea, Oviraptoridae, Ingeniinae
description: Remains of this dinosaur have been found with feathers preserved. Sexual differences can be seen in the plumage.

name: Confuciusornis
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Paraves, Eumaniraptoria, Avialae, Ornithurae, Avibrevicauda, Pygostylia, Confuciusornithidae
description: N/A

name: Corythosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Ornithopoda, Hadrosauridae, Lambeosaurinae
description:
Corythosaurus is a genus of hadrosaurid dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 77 to 75 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs commonly known as "duck-billed" or hadrosaurid dinosaurs. Corythosaurus was named for the distinctive crest on top of its skull, which resembles a helmet or crest of a medieval warrior. This crest was hollow and likely played a role in vocalization and possibly display.

This dinosaur reached lengths of around 9 to 10 meters (30 to 33 feet) and had a relatively slender build compared to other hadrosaurs. It walked on four legs but could also rear up on its hind legs to reach vegetation. Corythosaurus was herbivorous, feeding on a variety of plants such as ferns, conifers, and flowering plants. Fossils of Corythosaurus have been found in North America, particularly in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada, and the Two Medicine Formation of Montana, United States. It is one of the most well-known hadrosaurids and is important in understanding the diversity and ecology of Late Cretaceous dinosaurs.

name: Cryolophosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Tetanurae, Avetheropoda, Carnosauria
description: Cryolophosaurus is one of the earliest meat-eating dinosaurs found so far. It lived in what is now Antarctica and had a small curved crest on the top of its head.

name: Dacentrurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Thyreophora, Stegosauria, Stegosauridae
description: Dacentrurus was the first stegosaur ever discovered.

name: Daspletosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Tyrannosauroidea, Tyrannosauridae, Tyrannosaurinae
description:
Daspletosaurus is a genus of large carnivorous theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 77 to 75 million years ago. It belonged to the family Tyrannosauridae and is closely related to Tyrannosaurus rex. Daspletosaurus was one of the top predators of its time, occupying a similar ecological niche as T. rex but living slightly earlier in the Late Cretaceous.

Daspletosaurus was characterized by its massive size, powerful jaws filled with large, serrated teeth, and short, two-fingered forelimbs. It walked on two legs and had a robust build, reaching lengths of about 8 to 9 meters (26 to 30 feet) and weighing several tons. Fossils of Daspletosaurus have been found in North America, particularly in Alberta, Canada, and Montana, United States.

The name Daspletosaurus means "frightful lizard," reflecting its formidable appearance and predatory nature. It likely hunted large herbivorous dinosaurs such as ceratopsians and hadrosaurs. Daspletosaurus is an important species for understanding the evolution and ecology of large theropod dinosaurs during the Late Cretaceous period in North America.

name: Datousaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda
description:
Datousaurus is a genus of sauropod dinosaur that lived during the Middle Jurassic period, approximately 168 to 165 million years ago. It belonged to the group known as eusauropods, which included some of the largest land animals to ever exist. Datousaurus was discovered in China, specifically in the Upper Shaximiao Formation of Sichuan Province.

This dinosaur was characterized by its long neck, long tail, and massive body supported by four sturdy legs. While specific measurements are uncertain due to incomplete fossil material, Datousaurus is estimated to have been around 15 to 20 meters (49 to 66 feet) in length and weighed several tons. As a sauropod, Datousaurus was an herbivore, likely feeding on vegetation such as ferns, conifers, and cycads.

Although it is not as well-known as some other sauropod genera, Datousaurus contributes to our understanding of the diversity and evolution of sauropod dinosaurs during the Middle Jurassic period, particularly in Asia.

name: Deinocheirus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Ornithomimosauria
description: Originally, scientists only had a pair of arm bones with big, long claws to learn about Deinocheirus. But in 2014, new material revealed that it had a unique, large hump on its back, supported by its back bones. Now we know that it was a truly bizarre-looking creature, with huge, clawed hands, a beaked head like a duck and a hump like a camel.

name: Deinonychus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Dromaeosauridae
description: Deinonychus was a small meat-eating dinosaur. It lived in what is now North America during the Early Cretaceous Period.This dinosaur had a large, sickle-shaped talon on the second toe of each foot. When not in use the claw was held off the ground to keep it sharp.The species name - antirrhopus - means 'counterbalancing'. This is because Deinonychus' tail was long and stiff, helping to balance the animal's weight.When we talk about raptors, we are really talking about dromaeosaurs. 'Raptor' isn't a proper scientific term. Dromaeosaurs were all small- to medium-sized hunters with large toe claws.Some dromaeosaurs have the word 'raptor' in their names, such as Velociraptor, Bambiraptor and Utahraptor. But there are many others that don't, including Deinonychus and Achillobator. That's why it's misleading to call them all raptors.Deinonychus was a close relative of Velociraptor. When the latter featured in the novel Jurassic Park, the author based the dinosaur's details on the bigger Deinonychus. The film and sequels did the same.Nobody has found evidence to prove that Deinonychus had feathers. But scientists think it's very likely that it did.Some very closely related dinosaurs - including Velociraptor - definitely had them.The first Deinonychus fossils were found in southern Montana by John Ostrom and Grant Meyer in 1964. Ostrom published the findings and named the dinosaur five years later.His work caused a widespread change of opinion among palaeontologists. Before, people tended to think of dinosaurs as being slow, lumbering, cold-blooded beasts. Ostrom's studies helped scientists realise that they could be athletic, warm-blooded animals.This change of thought is sometimes called 'the dinosaur renaissance'. It brought a lot of new interest to the world of dinosaur science.Although Deinonychus is often portrayed as a fast-moving hunter, it may not have been as agile as we first imagined.Many researchers now think that Deinonychus wasn't especially quick on its feet compared to other dinosaurs, although it wouldn't have been slow as such.Deinonychus had relatively short lower leg bones. Some experts think that these may have evolved to help Deinonychus attack with its toe claws. They suggest that the shorter bones helped to absorb the impact of its slashing strikes.Other scientists aren't convinced that Deinonychus' toe claws were very effective as slashing weapons. They think the claws helped Deinonychus to climb or to pin smaller prey animals to the ground.Tenontosaurus and Zephyrosaurus may have been among the dinosaurs hunted by Deinonychus.

name: Dilophosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Dilophosauridae
description: Dilophosaurus was a fast-moving meat-eating dinosaur.  A kink in its upper jaw may mean that it ate a certain kind of food, or attacked by gripping and holding on to prey - modern crocodiles have a similar kink.The pair of thin bony crests on its head may have been for display.

name: Diplodocus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Diplodocoidea, Diplodocidae
description: Diplodocus had a long neck that it would have used to reach high and low vegetation, and to drink water. There has been some debate over how such a long neck would have been held.Scientists now think that ligaments running from the hip to the back of the neck would have allowed Diplodocus to hold its neck in a horizontal position without using muscles. The vertebrae (back bones) are split down the middle and this space could have held ligaments like these.Diplodocus may have had narrow, pointed bony spines lining its back.In 1905 a cast of a Diplodocus skeleton was donated to the Museum by the wealthy businessman Andrew Carnegie, based on the original specimen in the Carnegie Museum in the USA.King Edward VII had requested a copy of the newly discovered dinosaur after seeing a picture of it in Carnegie's Scottish castle. From 1979 to early 2017 the cast - known affectionately as Dippy - was on display in the Museum's Hintze Hall.In 1993, Dippy's tail was lifted from the ground after research revealed that Diplodocus tails would have been raised high to balance the neck.Every two years or so, our experts used specialist equipment to clean the 292 bones that make up Dippy. It took two staff two days to clean and maintain the cast for future generations to enjoy.In January 2017, Dippy left the Museum to prepare for a natural history adventure across the UK. After returning in 2022, the famous cast is now on display at the Herbert Art Gallery & Museum in Coventry, on long-term loan from the Museum.

name: Dreadnoughtus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda, Neosauropoda, Macronaria, Camarasauromorpha, Titanosauriformes, Titanosauria
description: Dreadnoughtus was a giant sauropod, a member of the group called titanosaurs. It lived in South America during the Cretaceous Period.Many titanosaurs are known from only a few bones, but scientists have found around half of the skeleton of Dreadnoughtus. This means it is better understood than some of the other giant sauropods of the time. The skull has never been found though. Thanks to having a good amount of fossil material to study, experts have been able to estimate the weight of this enormous dinosaur. A calculation published in 2020 puts the animal's weight at around 48 metric tons. That's about the same as eight African elephants! However, depending on the method used, estimates have ranged from 22 tonnes to 59 tonnes. The remains of only two Dreadnoughtus specimens have ever been uncovered. Scientists found that the largest one wasn't even fully grown. This means that nobody knows for sure how big this dinosaur could really get. The name Dreadnoughtus means 'fears nothing', because its enormous size would have made it difficult for predators to attack. It is also a reference to the dreadnoughts - huge battleships that fought in wars of the early twentieth century.Dreadnoughtus was so huge that it would have had to eat nearly constantly and spend as little energy as possible in order to survive. The dinosaur's long neck meant that it would have been able to reach a large variety of plant food sources without moving its body too much. This way, it would have been able to eat vast amounts without burning too many calories.The biggest Dreadnoughtus specimen ever found was not fully grown when it died, so scientists can't say for sure how large this dinosaur could grow in adulthood.As far as anyone can tell, some other huge titanosaurs, such as Patagotitan and Argentinosaurus, may have been bigger than Dreadnoughtus.Dreadnoughtus features in the Apple TV+ documentary, Prehistoric Planet. In this show, the dinosaur can be seen with inflatable air sacs on its neck. While there is no fossil evidence to show that Dreadnoughtus really had visible air sacs, all sauropod dinosaurs had internal air sacs.  These made the enormous animals lighter than they would otherwise have been. There is no doubt that many dinosaurs would have had surprising external soft tissue features. These features rarely get preserved as fossils - so for now, we can only guess at the unusual features that Dreadnoughtus might have had.

name: Dromaeosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Dromaeosauridae
description: The back foot of this dinosaur had a large claw for kicking.

name: Dromiceiomimus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Ornithomimosauria, Ornithomimidae
description: Dromiceiomimus looked very like a modern ostrich, but without the thick layer of feathers (it may have had some feathers).Dromiceiomimus is now a nomen dubium (dubious name), because the fossils are no longer thought to represent a distinct dinosaur type.

name: Dryosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Ornithopoda, Euornithopoda, Iguanadontia, Euiguanadontia, Dryomorpha, Dryosauridae
description:
Dryosaurus is a genus of ornithopod dinosaur that lived during the Late Jurassic period, approximately 155 to 145 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as ornithopods, characterized by their bipedal stance and herbivorous diet. Dryosaurus was a relatively small dinosaur, measuring about 4 to 6 meters (13 to 20 feet) in length.

This dinosaur had a slender build, with long hind limbs and shorter forelimbs ending in three-fingered hands. It had a beak-like mouth equipped with teeth suitable for cropping vegetation. Dryosaurus likely fed on a variety of plants, including ferns, conifers, and cycads. Fossils of Dryosaurus have been found in North America, particularly in the Morrison Formation of Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming.

Dryosaurus is notable for its agility and adaptations for swift locomotion, suggesting it may have been capable of evading predators such as Allosaurus. It is an important species for understanding the ecology and diversity of ornithopod dinosaurs during the Late Jurassic period.

name: Dryptosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Tyrannosauroidea
description: This dinosaur was originally named Laelaps by Edward Drinker Cope. His rival Othniel Charles Marsh realised that this name was already being used for a mite and renamed the dinosaur Dryptosaurus in 1877.

name: Edmontonia
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Thyreophora, Ankylosauria, Nodosauridae
description:
Edmontonia is a genus of ankylosaurid dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 76 to 74 million years ago. It was a heavily armored herbivore characterized by its thick, bony plates and spikes covering its body. Edmontonia belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as ankylosaurids, which were armored dinosaurs with a heavily fortified body plan for protection against predators.

This dinosaur had a low-slung body with four sturdy legs, a broad, heavily armored head, and a tail ending in a bony club. The bony plates and spikes on its body likely served as a form of defense against predators, such as large theropod dinosaurs like Tyrannosaurus rex. Fossils of Edmontonia have been found in North America, particularly in Alberta, Canada, and Montana, United States.

Edmontonia represents one of the more heavily armored ankylosaurids, with its robust armor providing insights into the evolutionary adaptations of dinosaurs for defense. It is an important species for understanding the diversity and ecology of Late Cretaceous dinosaurs in North America.

name: Elaphrosaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Neotheropoda, Ceratosauria, Neoceratosauria
description:
Elaphrosaurus is a genus of theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Jurassic period, around 155 to 150 million years ago. It was a relatively small dinosaur, estimated to have been about 4 to 5 meters (13 to 16 feet) in length. Elaphrosaurus belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as ceratosaurians, which were primitive theropods characterized by their slender build and three-toed feet.

Elaphrosaurus had a long, slender body with long legs adapted for swift movement. It likely had a bipedal stance, walking on two legs. Fossils of Elaphrosaurus have been found in Tanzania, Africa. The most distinctive feature of Elaphrosaurus is its long, low skull, which resembles that of some herbivorous dinosaurs. This feature has led to speculation about its diet and feeding behavior, with some suggesting it may have been an herbivore or omnivore rather than a carnivore like most other theropods.

However, most paleontologists believe that Elaphrosaurus was indeed a carnivore, using its sharp teeth and agile body to hunt small prey such as lizards and small mammals. Despite its relatively small size and less well-known status compared to other theropods, Elaphrosaurus is important for understanding the early diversity of predatory dinosaurs and their evolutionary adaptations.

name: Emausaurus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Thyreophora
description:
Emausaurus is a genus of small herbivorous dinosaur that lived during the Late Triassic period, approximately 210 to 200 million years ago. It belonged to a group of dinosaurs called prosauropods, which were early relatives of the gigantic sauropods that would dominate the later Mesozoic era.

Emausaurus was relatively small, reaching lengths of about 2 to 3 meters (6.6 to 9.8 feet) and weighing around 100 kilograms (220 pounds). It had a bipedal stance, meaning it walked on two legs, but it likely had the ability to occasionally move on all fours. This dinosaur had a long neck and tail, and it had relatively small, leaf-shaped teeth, indicating it was an herbivore that fed on plants.

Fossils of Emausaurus have been found in Germany, particularly in the Stuttgart region. These fossils have provided valuable insights into the early evolution of sauropodomorph dinosaurs and the ecological dynamics of the Late Triassic period.

name: Eolambia
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Ornithopoda, Euornithopoda, Iguanadontia, Euiguanadontia, Dryomorpha, Ankylopollexia, Iguanodontoidea
description: Eolambia is known from the skulls and postcrania of several individuals, both juveniles and adults.

name: Eoraptor
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda
description:
Eoraptor is a genus of small, early theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Triassic period, approximately 231 to 228 million years ago. It is one of the earliest known dinosaurs and represents an important transitional form in the evolutionary history of dinosaurs.

Eoraptor was relatively small, measuring about 1 to 2 meters (3 to 6 feet) in length and weighing around 10 to 15 kilograms (22 to 33 pounds). It had a bipedal stance, walking on two legs, and it possessed sharp, serrated teeth adapted for feeding on small prey. However, some scientists also suggest that Eoraptor may have been omnivorous, meaning it could have consumed both meat and plants.

Fossils of Eoraptor have been found in Argentina, particularly in the Ischigualasto Formation. This dinosaur is significant because it provides crucial insights into the early stages of dinosaur evolution, including the emergence of key anatomical features that would later characterize various dinosaur groups. Eoraptor's discovery has helped paleontologists better understand the origins and diversification of dinosaurs during the Late Triassic period.

name: Euhelopus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Sauropodomorpha, Sauropoda, Eusauropoda
description: Euhelopus is known from a skull and partial postcranial skeletons.

name: Euoplocephalus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Thyreophora, Ankylosauria, Ankylosauridae
description: Euoplocephalus had bony spikes and armour plating on its back, and a bony tail club used for defence.

name: Eustreptospondylus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Megalosauridae, Eustreptospondylinae
description:
Eustreptospondylus is a genus of theropod dinosaur that lived during the Middle Jurassic period, approximately 165 to 161 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as megalosaurs, which were medium to large-sized carnivores characterized by their bipedal stance and sharp teeth.

Eustreptospondylus was a relatively large theropod, estimated to have been around 5 to 6 meters (16 to 20 feet) in length. It had a robust build, with powerful hind limbs and a long, flexible tail that likely helped with balance and agility. Its arms were relatively short compared to its body size, ending in hands with three fingers bearing sharp claws.

Fossils of Eustreptospondylus have been found in England, particularly in the Oxford Clay Formation. It is one of the earliest known megalosaurs and provides valuable insights into the diversity of theropod dinosaurs during the Middle Jurassic period in Europe. Eustreptospondylus likely preyed upon smaller dinosaurs and other animals, using its powerful jaws and claws to capture and consume its prey.

name: Gallimimus
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda, Ornithomimosauria, Ornithomimidae
description:
Gallimimus is a genus of theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 70 to 66 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as ornithomimids, which were characterized by their long, slender limbs and bird-like features. Gallimimus was one of the largest members of this group.

Gallimimus was a bipedal dinosaur, meaning it walked on two legs, and it had a lightweight build, similar to modern-day ostriches. It reached lengths of about 6 meters (20 feet) and weighed around 440 kilograms (970 pounds). Gallimimus had a small head with a toothless beak and large eyes, indicating it likely had keen eyesight.

Fossils of Gallimimus have been found in Mongolia, particularly in the Nemegt Formation. It is known for its remarkable speed and agility, and it is often considered one of the fastest dinosaurs. Gallimimus likely fed on a variety of small animals and plants, using its speed to outrun predators or catch prey. It is also famous for its appearance in the movie Jurassic Park, where it was depicted in a stampede scene.

name: Tyranosaurus Rex
whenLived: Late Cretaceous Period, approximately 68 to 66 million years ago
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Theropoda,Tyrannosauridae,Tyrannosaurus
description:
Tyrannosaurus rex, often abbreviated as T. rex, is renowned as one of the most formidable predators to have roamed the Earth. With an impressive length of around 12.3 to 12.8 meters (40 to 42 feet) from snout to tail and standing approximately 4 meters (13 feet) tall at the hips, T. rex commanded attention with its massive size. Its robust skull boasted powerful jaws lined with serrated teeth, some measuring up to 30 centimeters (12 inches) in length. Despite its imposing stature, T. rex had relatively small forelimbs with only two fingers on each hand, contrasting sharply with its large and powerful hind limbs.

As a bipedal dinosaur, T. rex moved on two legs, its body balanced by a long, heavy tail. This posture facilitated swift and efficient movement, allowing it to navigate diverse environments ranging from forests to plains and river valleys in western North America during the Late Cretaceous Period, approximately 68 to 66 million years ago.

As a carnivore, T. rex was a top predator, likely feeding on a variety of large herbivorous dinosaurs that shared its habitat. Its formidable jaws and teeth were adapted for delivering powerful bites, enabling it to consume large chunks of flesh from its prey. While much of its behavior remains speculative, T. rex is believed to have been an apex predator, utilizing its size, strength, and keen senses to locate and capture prey.

Overall, Tyrannosaurus rex symbolizes the epitome of carnivorous evolution during the Late Cretaceous, captivating imaginations with its awe-inspiring presence and leaving an indelible mark on our understanding of prehistoric life.

name: Tricerotops
whenLived: Late Cretaceous period, approximately 68 to 66 million years ago.
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Ceratopsia, Ceratopsidae, Triceratops
description:
Triceratops is a genus of herbivorous dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 68 to 66 million years ago. It belonged to the group of dinosaurs known as ceratopsids, characterized by their large, bony frills and three facial horns. Triceratops is one of the most iconic and well-known dinosaurs, often recognized for its distinctive appearance and role in popular culture.

Triceratops was a massive dinosaur, reaching lengths of about 8 to 9 meters (26 to 30 feet) and weighing several tons. It had a quadrupedal stance, meaning it walked on four sturdy legs, and its body was heavily built with a broad, shield-like frill at the back of its skull. The most notable feature of Triceratops is its facial horns: two long horns above its eyes and a shorter horn on its nose.

Fossils of Triceratops have been found in North America, particularly in the Western United States, including states such as Montana, Wyoming, and South Dakota. Triceratops likely fed on low-lying vegetation, such as ferns and cycads, using its powerful beak and teeth to grind plant material. It is also known to have engaged in intra-species combat, as evidenced by injuries and horn damage observed in some fossils. Triceratops is an important species for understanding the diversity and ecology of Late Cretaceous dinosaurs and remains a popular subject of study and fascination in paleontology.

name: Stegosaurus
whenLived: Late Jurassic period, approximately 155 to 150 million years ago
taxonomy: Dinosauria, Ornithischia, Thyreophora, Stegosauria, Stegosauridae
description: Stegosaurus is a genus of herbivorous dinosaur known for its distinctive appearance, characterized by a row of large, upright plates along its back and pairs of spikes at the end of its tail. This dinosaur lived during the Late Jurassic period, approximately 155 to 150 million years ago, in what is now western North America. Stegosaurus had a heavily built body supported by four sturdy legs and a small head positioned on the end of a short neck. It was an herbivore, likely feeding on low-lying vegetation such as ferns, cycads, and conifers. Stegosaurus is one of the most iconic dinosaurs and remains a popular subject of fascination in paleontology and popular culture.
